questions.text: What does this road sign mean?
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the national speed limit applies to the road. On single carriageways, this is 60 mph for cars.

questions.text: You are driving on a motorway. What is the speed limit for cars and motorcycles?
questions.explanation: The national speed limit on motorways for cars and motorcycles is 70 mph, unless signs show otherwise.

questions.text: You see a pedestrian with a white stick and red band. This shows the person is:
questions.explanation: A white stick with a red band indicates that the person is deaf and blind. Extra care should be taken as they cannot see or hear approaching vehicles.

questions.text: When may you sound the horn on your vehicle?
options: To give you right of way
To warn others of your presence
To make slower drivers move over
questions.explanation: You may only sound your horn to warn other road users of your presence. It should not be used aggressively or between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am in built-up areas.

questions.text: What is the most important reason for having a properly adjusted head restraint?
options: To help you avoid neck injury
To help you maintain your driving position
questions.explanation: A properly adjusted head restraint will help prevent whiplash injuries in the event of a collision from behind.

questions.text: You are driving in heavy rain. Your steering suddenly becomes very light. What should you do?
options: Steer towards the side of the road
questions.explanation: This is aquaplaning - when water builds up between your tyres and the road surface. Ease off the accelerator and slow down gradually. Do not brake or turn the steering wheel suddenly.

questions.text: You are about to overtake a cyclist. Which one of the following is the main hazard you should be aware of?
options: The cyclist may get off the bike
The cyclist may move to the left
The cyclist may swerve out into the road
questions.explanation: Cyclists may swerve out to avoid drains, potholes, or debris. Always give them plenty of room when overtaking.

questions.text: You are driving on a motorway. The car ahead shows its hazard warning lights for a short time. This tells you that:
options: The driver wants you to overtake
The car ahead is about to change lanes
Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly
The car is about to stop on the hard shoulder
questions.explanation: On motorways, briefly using hazard lights warns following traffic of a hazard ahead, usually stationary or slow-moving traffic.

questions.text: What should you do when driving in fog?
options: Use fog lights if visibility is less than 100 metres
questions.explanation: You must use fog lights when visibility is seriously reduced, generally when you cannot see for more than 100 metres (328 feet).

questions.text: At an incident, a casualty is unconscious but still breathing. You should only move them if:
options: Bystanders will help you move them
An ambulance is on its way
questions.explanation: You should only move a casualty if there is further danger, such as risk of fire or further collisions. Moving them unnecessarily could cause further injury.
